text: I was flying hurricanes in a bomber
operational training unit in that
hurricane we had a radio call tr9 and
what I was able to do in that hurricane
was to switch the TR 9 radio from the
call from honeybourne to the BBC forces
program I think I said the war is over
the war is over and so I did a great big
barrel roll around the Wellington bomber
landed back at honeybourne got a lifted
to tell them out where my wife and
daughter work and went in the nearest
boozer that was a selling beer and had a
few that was me very humdrum there no
gallon story about shooting down
anything just a humdum teaching or
instructing bombing the crews at all to
think one how lucky i have been but also
to remember those that didn't come back
and you know there were one or two that
were very clear is it important and if
it is important why is it important that
we should remember this anniversary as
pitiful freedom the freedom to choose
yes indeed and you feel that you and all
the others did make a difference yes in
the terms of the wall I wish we could
make a difference in them peaceful you
know it because the whole world seems at
war now that we eat day that is
something nobody bothered to pull blinds
and it put switches on everywhere the
electric Sharum lights on the road it
was really good
it was good because we walked
effectively in the dark for many years
everyone at the brigade women that were
on duty had soldiers either husbands who
were in reserved occupations or soldiers
who were in Europe so they were all
coming home and there was I know husband
I didn't see him for four years and
seven months after he left in july two
days after governor it it's important to
remember the war and i think that's very
important because a lot of people of
their lives a lot of people and you
wonder if it was worth it something
